content:
some of the things I want to fix are

  • the standard library
    • https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/issues/932
    • https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/issues/873
  • making things easier to find
    • https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/issues/866
    • https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/issues/831
    • https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/issues/775
    • https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/issues/853
    • https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/issues/674
I've got a heck of a lot of free time lately
so, most time. i should make lunch first
oh do you have time now-ish? If you want to do this in a half hour or so that works for me :)
let me see what it's missing from https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/contributing.html
well for starters, it's completely missing 'what do you want to do' and assumes you want to build the compiler :laughing:
would you like this all via zulip or some sort of voice call thing? the voice call would perhaps be harder to transcribe later, but it would give you more genuine feedback
discord voice calls work for me, how does that sound?
actually I think vscode has a 'remote editing' feature, I wonder if I could set that up somehow
i've seen it used but never turned it on myself
(trying to get it to work, one sec)

so I don't forget: we did not change much of the dev-guide, but the two main takeaways were
a) x.py is bad at detecting the target platform on windows (it thinks you have GNU if uname works, even if you don't have a GNU compiler). This could be fixed by looking at rustup default.
b) x.py setup doesn't run until the rust code runs, which means if your toolchain is broken you don't see it at all. This is a little harder to fix - maybe it could be moved into python? I'd prefer to keep things in rust as much as possible, though ...
oh and also x.py setup should take 1/2/3/4 as inputs, not just a/b/c/d
